chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Managing common minor ailments
chapter.summary: Covers the management of some common minor ailments which may be experienced during pregnancy.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 18 years to 40 years (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Nausea and vomiting
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Reassure the woman that nausea and vomiting in pregnancy usually resolves by around 16 weeks of pregnancy and is not associated with an increased risk of poor pregnancy outcome.
  • For relief of mild nausea and vomiting, consider advising the use of ginger (which can be fresh or in the form of ginger-containing food items, teas, tinctures, or tablets) or P6 (wrist) acupressure.
  • If an anti-emetic is required in pregnancy, prescribe oral promethazine or oral cyclizine, and reassess after 24 hours (all anti-emetics are unlicensed for treatment of nausea and vomiting in pregnancy).
    • If the response to the treatment is good, continue treatment with the chosen anti-emetic (promethazine or cyclizine), review the woman once a week, and stop when possible.
    • If the response to treatment is inadequate, the woman is not dehydrated, and there is no ketonuria:
      • Switch to another anti-emetic such as oral metoclopramide, oral prochlorperazine, or oral ondansetron. 
      • Reassess the woman after 24 hours.
    • If the response to the second-line anti-emetic is good, continue treatment, review the woman once a week, and stop when possible.
    • If the response to the second-line anti-emetic is poor, seek specialist advice.
  • Seek urgent advice if the woman is dehydrated or has ketonuria despite drug treatment, as intravenous rehydration may be required.
  • Use clinical judgement to decide when to stop medication. 
    • It may be possible to stop anti-emetic medication at around 12–16 weeks, as at this time symptoms usually improve.
    • Take into account severity of symptoms, response to treatment in previous pregnancies, and also the preference of the woman.
  • For more detailed information on how to manage nausea and vomiting in pregnancy, see the CKS topic on Nausea/vomiting in pregnancy. 
  • The UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) has freely available bumps patient information leaflets on Treating nausea and vomiting in pregnancy and Use of ondansetron in pregnancy.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on treating nausea and vomiting in pregnancy are based on expert opinion in the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Antenatal care for uncomplicated pregnancies [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010a] and from the UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) [UKTIS, 2015a].

Anti-emetics
  • Metoclopramide is not licensed for people under 20 years old (known to cause oculogyric crisis, especially in young adults) and the maximum duration of treatment is 5 days [BNF 71, 2016].
  • Ondansetron is significantly more expensive than metoclopramide or prochlorperazine, and has been associated in some (but not all) studies with an increased risk of heart defects in the baby. However, use after the 8th gestational week would not be expected to increase the risk of heart defects [BNF 71, 2016; UKTIS, 2015a].

• Advise on dietary measures, including adequate fibre and fluid intake to prevent or treat constipation in pregnancy.
  • Advise that regular light or moderate exercise can also be helpful.
  • Laxatives should be considered only if dietary measures fail.
    • A bulk-forming laxative is a reasonable first-line choice.
    • If stools remain hard, add or switch to lactulose or a macrogol.
    • If stools are soft but the woman still finds them difficult to pass or complains of inadequate emptying, consider a short course of bisacodyl or senna.
    • Occasional use of glycerol or bisacodyl suppositories are also an option.
  • For detailed information on how to manage constipation in pregnancy, see the section on Pregnancy or breastfeeding in the CKS topic on Constipation. 
  • The UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) has a freely available bumps patient information leaflet on Treating constipation in pregnancy.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The recommendations on treating constipation in pregnancy are based on expert opinion in the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Antenatal care for uncomplicated pregnancies [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010a], a Department of Health (DoH) publication The Pregnancy Book [DH, 2016a], and from a scientific review of the available evidence carried out by the UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) [UKTIS, 2013].

• Reassure the woman that varicose veins are common in pregnancy, are not harmful to the baby, and often improve considerably after pregnancy
  • Offer treatment with compression stockings; these may improve the symptoms but will not prevent varicose veins from emerging.
  • For more detailed information, see the CKS topics on Varicose veins and Compression stockings.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The recommendations on treating varicose veins in pregnancy are based on expert opinion in the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Antenatal care for uncomplicated pregnancies [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010a] and a Department of Health (DoH) publication The Pregnancy Book [DH, 2016a].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Dyspepsia/heartburn
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Initially offer the woman information regarding lifestyle and diet modification such as eating smaller meals more frequently, avoiding fatty and spicy foods and caffeine, and raising the head of the bed.
  • Antacids or alginates are recommended as first-line treatments if symptoms are relatively mild and are not controlled adequately by lifestyle changes.
    • Antacid products containing combinations of aluminium and magnesium are recommended on an as-required basis.
    • Calcium-containing products are recommended only for short-term or occasional use.
    • Alginate products are particularly useful if symptoms of gastro-oesophageal reflux are dominant.
  • If symptoms are severe or persist despite treatment with an antacid or alginate, consider prescribing an acid-suppressing drug.
    • Omeprazole is licensed for use in pregnancy.
    • Ranitidine is commonly used in pregnancy but is not licensed for such use.
  • For more detailed information, see the CKS topic on Dyspepsia - pregnancy-associated. 
  • The UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) has freely available bumps patient information leaflets on Use of ranitidine in pregnancy and Use of Omeprazole in pregnancy.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on treating dyspepsia/heartburn in pregnancy are based on expert opinion in the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Antenatal care for uncomplicated pregnancies [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010a]. Further information is derived from a Department of Health (DoH) publication The Pregnancy Book [DH, 2016a].

Ranitidine and omeprazole
  • Information on the pregnancy safety of ranitidine and omeprazole is based on reviews of the available scientific evidence carried out by the UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) [UKTIS, 2015b; UKTIS, 2015c].

• Advise the woman that an increase in vaginal discharge is normal during pregnancy.
  • If the discharge is associated with itch, soreness, offensive smell, or pain on passing urine, investigate for an underlying cause, such as bacterial vaginosis, vaginal candidiasis, or trichomoniasis, and manage as appropriate. For more information, see the CKS topics on Vaginal discharge, Bacterial vaginosis, Candida - female genital, and Trichomoniasis. The UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) has a freely available bump patient information leaflet on Use of clotrimazole in pregnancy.
  • If a sexually transmitted infection is suspected, offer the woman access to testing, treatment and support.
    • This service may be provided by general practice (where appropriate training and facilities exist), community sexual and reproductive health services, or a genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinic.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The recommendations on managing and treating vaginal discharge in pregnancy are based on expert opinion in the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Antenatal Care for Uncomplicated Pregnancies [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010a]. Further information is derived from a Department of Health (DoH) publication The Pregnancy Book [DH, 2016a].

• Advise the women that exercising in water, massage therapy, and group or individual back care classes might help to ease back pain during pregnancy.
  • Paracetamol is generally considered to be safe to use in pregnancy. 
    • The UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) has a freely available bumps patient information leaflet on Use of paracetamol in pregnancy.
  • Women with severe back pain should be advised to see their GP, who may be able to prescribe alternative analgesia and may recommend referral to a physiotherapist. For more information, see the CKS topic on Back pain - low (without radiculopathy).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The recommendations on treating backache in pregnancy are based on expert opinion in the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Antenatal Care for Uncomplicated Pregnancies [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010a], and a Department of Health (DoH) publication The Pregnancy Book [DH, 2016a].

• Offer the woman advice to minimize constipation and straining:
    • Advise an increase in daily fibre and fluid intake to promote soft, bulky, regular stools. This can help to relieve constipation and reduce straining.
    • Discourage straining during defecation, which can exacerbate symptoms of haemorrhoids.
  • Advise the woman about perianal hygiene, as this may be helpful in relieving symptoms and preventing perineal dermatitis.
  • If symptoms remain troublesome, offer treatment with a topical haemorrhoidal preparation. Be aware that they are not licensed for use during pregnancy, although they are commonly used on the basis that:
    • The active ingredients will only reach the baby in extremely small amounts.
    • Use is generally short-term. 
    • Haemorrhoids do not usually develop in pregnancy until after the first trimester when all of the baby's organs are formed. Use of a medicine after this time will therefore not cause structural birth defects in the baby.
  • For more detailed information, see the CKS topic on Haemorrhoids. 
  • The UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) has a freely available bumps patient information leaflet on Treating Haemorrhoids in pregnancy.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The recommendations on treating haemorrhoids in pregnancy are based on expert opinion in the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Antenatal Care for Uncomplicated Pregnancies [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2010a], a Department of Health (DoH) publication The Pregnancy Book [DH, 2016a], and from a scientific review of the available evidence carried out by the UK Teratology Information Service (UKTIS) [UKTIS, 2016].
